summary: This is a New York Police Department burglary investigation report from August 2012. It documents a follow-up investigation at a Manhattan property, where a property manager allowed officers to review surveillance video, which captured no suspects. The case remained active.

persons.name: Reporting Officer
persons.context: The officer who filed this burglary investigation report. Their specific name is not provided in the visible text.

persons.name: Reviewing Supervisor
persons.context: The supervisor who reviewed the police report. Their specific name is not provided in the visible text.

persons.name: Property Manager
persons.context: The property manager for an unspecified individual (potentially 'Mr. [Redacted]') who allowed the investigating officers to review surveillance video from the premises.

events.title: Video Review for Burglary Investigation
events.description: Investigating officers met with a property manager at a Manhattan location to review surveillance camera footage related to a burglary complaint. The video captured no suspects.

events.title: Burglary Complaint Filed
events.description: The initial complaint for burglary was filed with the NYPD's 19th Precinct, generating Complaint No. 2012-019-05703.

keyFacts: A burglary investigation was active in Manhattan in August 2012, with the NYPD's 19th Precinct and Detective Squad involved.
On August 28, 2012, officers reviewed surveillance video from the property with the manager, but the video captured no suspects.
The document is a standard NYPD follow-up investigation report, indicating the case remained active as of the report date.
The property in question is located at or near the intersection of Madison Avenue and 5th Avenue in Manhattan.
The document reference (EFTA00102694) is part of the Epstein case files, suggesting this property or investigation may have a connection to the broader case.
